results.title: Zoetrope and praxinoscope
results.brief_description: In 1834, two years after the phenakistoscope was invented in Europe, British mathematician William George Horner created his own version, the zoetrope, which used a cylindrical viewing drum containing a strip of sequenced pictures viewable through thin slits.

constellations_primary.name: Optical toys, Totoro and terrors
constellations_primary.description: Victorian-era optical toys have inspired the biggest animation studios and the scariest horror films.

results.description:
In 1834, two years after the phenakistoscope was invented in Europe, British mathematician William George Horner created his own version of the optical illusion. The Daedalum, or ‘wheel of the Devil’, used a cylindrical viewing drum containing a strip of sequenced pictures viewable through thin slits. When rotated it created the illusion of motion, and it became known as the zoetrope.

Over 40 years later, in 1877, French showman and lantern painter Charles-Émile Reynaud developed the praxinoscope, replacing the narrow viewing slots in Horner’s design with an inner circle of mirrors that more brightly reflected the pictures and let more than one person view the gliding images.
description_for_label:
In 1834, two years after the phenakistoscope was invented in Europe, British mathematician William George Horner created his own version of the optical illusion. The Daedalum, or ‘wheel of the Devil’, used a cylindrical viewing drum containing a strip of sequenced pictures viewable through thin slits. When rotated it created the illusion of motion, and it became known as the zoetrope.

Over 40 years later, in 1877, French showman and lantern painter Charles-Émile Reynaud developed the praxinoscope, replacing the narrow viewing slots in Horner’s design with an inner circle of mirrors that more brightly reflected the pictures and let more than one person view the gliding images.

group_works.title: Large green zoetrope with metal base

results.title: Zoetrope
results.brief_description: Animation device called Zoetrope and assorted animation strips. Body of Zoetrope is a cylinder formation closed on bottom and open at top with a series of slits around top rim and painted green. Wood spindle joins cylinder to metal tiered stand. Zoetrope has five various themed printed paper animation strips depicting illustrations of a sequence of drawings showing motion. Animation strips are either black and white or mono coloured with an animation on both sides.

results.title: Zlateh the Goat
results.creator_credit: Weston Woods Studios, Morton Schindel and Gene Deitch
results.brief_description: Winter is late so for Reuven the furrier it is a bad year. After long hesitation he decides to sell Zlateh the goat. However, the pet goat is spared from the butcher’s knife when she saves her young master from a snowstorm.

results.title: Zirconia: the toughest ceramic
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Researchers”.
Partially stabilized zirconia (or PSZ) is a new development in industrial ceramics and is probably the toughest ceramic ever made. Developed by researchers at CSIRO’s Division of Materials Science, PSZ has a number of unique properties which make it suitable for a variety of engineering applications.

results.title: Zipper: great moments in art and fashion
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, colour and audio

results.title: Zinc
results.creator_credit: BBC-TV, Open University and Barrie Whatley
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Principles of Chemical Processes”.
Electrochemistry, thermodynamics and chemical kinetics are used to provide the basis for explaining the industrial extraction of zinc from its ores.

results.title: Zimbabwe, Botswana & Namibia
results.creator_credit: Pilot Films, Phil Frank and Stephen Lennhoff
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Lonely planet: the experience”.
Join Andrew Daddo as he explores Zimbabwe, Botswana and Namibia in another ‘Lonely Planet’ travel video. Bungee jump above the Zambezi river, snack on the delicacy of boiled worms, come face to face with a pride of lions, canoe through crocodile infested waters and ride in a dunebuggy over the Namibia desert.

results.title: Ziegfeld Follies
results.creator_credit: Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, Arthur Freed and Vincente Minnelli
results.brief_description: In a brief introductory passage, the now-dead showman, Ziegfield (William Powell), reminisces over his past triumphs (very well depicted with puppets). He then plans, from Heaven, a new “Follies”. The elaborate acts of his vision follow, with Fred Astaire, Lucille Bremer, Lucille Ball, Lena Horne, Gene Kelly, Esther Williams, Judy Garland and Kathryn Grayson. Interspersed are three good comedy routines featuring Victor Moore, Ed Arnold, Fanny Brice, Hume Cronin and Red Skelton.

results.title: Zhenzhen's Beauty Parlor = Zhen Zhen Fa Wu
results.creator_credit: Youth Film Studio and Xu Tongjun
results.brief_description:
After having a falling out with her old boss at the beauty parlour, the female hairdresser Zhenzhen decides to take control of her own destiny and set up her own operation across the street. However, tempers flare when she flies in the cool Hong Kong stylist Ah Ming to lift her game, and the street begins to feel too small for the two beauty parlours. Thus begins the drama of Zhenzhen’s Beauty Parlour.

After Ah Ming meets Zhenzhen at station, it is not long before there is a partial nudity scene and a faceoff between two opposing beauty parlours. Obviously Ah Ming does not realise what he has walked into. Not only does the animosity between the two shops create an air of hostility in the little street, but he feels that he’s being swindled when Zhenzhen bargains him down to a 30/70 share of the profits. Ah Ming dissatisfied with the lack of customers and so he does what any suave modern Cantonese would do: He whips out his sax.

It’s not long before Ah Ming has drawn the attention of the more conservative members of society (usually shown as women and mothers). His fancy elaborate hairdos are controversial and widely talked about by the locals. And the two partners have a falling out when Zhenzhen doens’t want to do an outlandish punk hairstyle out of fear of scaring customers off.

Cai Xiang, the owner of their rival parlour, turns out to be Zhenzhen’s former lover, and though he still has feelings for her, he agrees to hook up with a long-time admirer who runs the tobacconist. The tobacconist doesn’t mind, believing that he will grow to love her with time. His only condition is that she put a stop to the rumors she has been spreading about Zhenzhen
After a string of minor incidents and hardships, the two former lovers make up and everyone lives happily ever after.
(2 stars - James Donald; 10 June, 2011)

Note: Adapted from the novel ‘The Troubleshooter’ by Wang Shuo.
